qas.question: What pact contained many Russian-speaking countries?
Where was Russian schooling mandatory in the 20th century?

answers.text: Poland, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Hungary, Albania, former East Germany and Cuba

qas.question: Which countries speak other Slavic languages?

answers.text: Poland, Czech Republic, Slovakia, and Bulgaria

qas.question: What pact was formed by Cuba?
What three countries are former satellites of East Germany?
Where is Polish no longer mandatory?
What is the fluency in Polish in some countries according to the Eurobarometer?

context: In the 20th century, Russian was mandatorily taught in the schools of the members of the old <a0_0><b3_0>Warsaw Pact<b3_0/><a0_0/> and in other countries that used to be satellites of the USSR. In particular, these countries include <a1_0><b4_0>Poland, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic<b4_0/>, Slovakia, Hungary, Albania, former East Germany and Cuba<a1_0/>. However, younger generations are usually not fluent in it, because Russian is no longer mandatory <b5_0>in the school system<b5_0/>. According to the Eurobarometer 2005 survey, though, fluency in Russian remains <b6_0>fairly high (20–40%)<b6_0/> in some countries, in particular those where the people speak a Slavic language and thereby have an edge in learning Russian (namely, <a2_0>Poland, Czech Republic, Slovakia, and Bulgaria<a2_0/>).
